葡萄牙北部锂资源丰富地区的一个市政府周四表示，将于下周提起诉讼，阻止总部位于伦敦的萨凡纳资源公司开发四个露天矿，并补充说，与“绿色”能源交易相关的持续腐败丑闻已导致为其战斗提供了助力。

葡萄牙总理安东尼奥·科斯塔周二下台，此前检察官拘留了他的幕僚长，并将他的基础设施部长列为对政府处理利润丰厚的锂和氢项目涉嫌违法行为的调查的正式嫌疑人。

葡萄牙已知锂储量超过 60,000 吨，是欧洲最大的锂生产国，但其矿商几乎全部销售给陶瓷行业。

随着欧洲寻求开发自己的战略能源以减少对中国和其他供应商的依赖，他们现在正准备生产用于电池的更高等级的锂。

环境机构APA今年早些时候批准了葡萄牙Lusorecursos公司在蒙塔莱格雷北部提取电池级锂，并批准了Savannah Resources (SAVS.L)在同样位于北部的博蒂卡斯开发矿山。

萨凡纳表示，它正在与当局合作，当局已视察了其部分地点，但该公司及其任何员工都不是调查的目标。

博蒂卡斯市市长费尔南多·奎罗加 (Fernando Queiroga) 告诉路透社，他的团队正在完成针对萨凡纳采矿计划的诉讼，该诉讼是在 5 月份 APA 获得环境批准后发起的，计划于下周提起诉讼。

APA 主席努诺·拉卡斯塔 (Nuno Lacasta) 也被列为正在进行的调查中的嫌疑人。 APA 证实，作为调查的一部分，其办公室已被搜查，并表示审批程序符合法律。

“当然，我们现在将（在诉讼中）纳入已经曝光的消息，”奎罗加说。 “毫无疑问，这给了我们更多的论据和更多的力量。”

萨凡纳表示，它“一直并将始终以完全合法和透明的方式开展业务”。

锂项目遭到当地居民和环保人士的强烈反对。他们表示，这些流程缺乏透明度，并警告决策者和矿业公司之间存在“危险的混乱”。

葡萄牙反采矿组织敦促当局在调查期间暂停并审查所有锂项目。

乌克兰议会周四批准了明年的国家预算，旨在加强其军队和国防，因为基辅与俄罗斯之间的战争持续了 20 个月，而且还没有结束的迹象。

预算收入定为 1.77 万亿格里夫尼亚（484 亿美元），而支出计划为 3.35 万亿格里夫尼亚。政府官员表示，2024年乌克兰将面临约435.8亿美元的巨额预算赤字。

明年，乌克兰预算支出的一半以上计划用于国防部门，为针对俄罗斯的战争提供资金，俄罗斯于 2022 年 2 月发动了全面入侵。

“预算中明确规定了优先事项。我们将动用所有内部资源，以便我们能够抵御并战胜敌人，”总理丹尼斯·什米哈尔在投票后表示。

“我们支出的近50%用于乌克兰的国防和安全。将会有更多的武器和车辆、更多的无人机、弹药和导弹。纳税人的每一格里夫纳都将流向军队。”

什米哈尔还表示，政府计划提高最低工资和养老金，以帮助数百万人应对战争期间不断上涨的生活成本。

立法者表示，276 名代表投票支持该预算，该预算还设想明年教育和卫生部门的支出增加。

财政部长谢尔盖·马尔琴科表示，乌克兰西方盟国的财政援助对于弥补预算缺口并支付社会和人道主义支出至关重要。

政府今年已从合作伙伴那里收到了 354 亿美元，去年则收到了约 310 亿美元。

但明年获得外国资金支持可能会更具挑战性。马尔琴科承认，随着战争的拖延，捐助者的疲劳感也在加剧。

政府计划明年经济增长，预计国内生产总值 (GDP) 增长 4.6%，而今年预期增长近 5%。

去年，乌克兰经济萎缩了近三分之一，数百万人逃离战争，城镇遭到轰炸，关键基础设施遭到破坏，供应和物流链严重中断。

随着战争进入第 21 个月，企业和人们已经适应了新的战时现实。然而，政府和分析师表示，风险和不确定性仍然很高。

周四，两个最高法院就被监禁的议会议员坎·阿塔莱(Can Atalay)一案发生的纠纷引发了人们对土耳其法治的担忧，这位议员的律师将上诉法院的举动描述为“司法政变企图”。

周三，最高上诉法院（Yargitay）采取了史无前例的步骤，对宪法法院法官提出刑事申诉，称他们上个月支持释放阿塔莱的裁决违宪。

这场争吵恰逢欧盟委员会发布关于土耳其长期停滞的欧盟入盟申请的年度报告，批评其在民主标准、法治、人权和司法独立方面“严重倒退”。

47 岁的阿塔莱去年与土耳其慈善家奥斯曼·卡瓦拉和其他六人一起，因在 2013 年组织全国抗议活动试图推翻政府而被判处 18 年监禁。

所有被告均否认有关抗议活动的指控，他们称抗议活动是自发发展的，这是塔伊普·埃尔多安总统执政二十年来面临的最大的公众挑战。

阿塔莱的律师奥兹古尔·乌尔法（Ozgur Urfa）表示：“最高法院不承认宪法法院的裁决，从而犯下了罪行。这是一次司法政变企图。”

他呼吁遵守宪法法院的裁决，并表示应该对亚吉泰上诉法院的法官进行调查。

然而，埃尔多安首席顾问穆罕默德·乌库姆为亚吉塔的举动进行了辩护。

“宪法法院继续做出违宪决定，”他在社交媒体平台X（前身为Twitter）上表示，辩称其关于被定罪议员议会豁免权的决定是违宪的。

欧洲议会土耳其报告员纳乔·桑切斯·阿莫尔对这一争端表示不安。

阿莫尔在 X 上表示：“这引发了一场前所未有的制度危机，并证实了欧洲委员会和欧盟多年来对土耳其司法部门表达的所有担忧。”

此次司法冲突发生之际，该国自五月选举以来经济政策大转变，转向更加正统，目前正寻求吸引外国投资者。

土耳其经济沙皇穆罕默德·西姆塞克和央行行长哈菲兹·盖伊·埃尔坎一直在西方首都和中东举行投资者会议。

周四，以色列军队在加沙地带北部的废墟建筑中与哈马斯武装分子作战，随着被围困的巴勒斯坦领土上平民的困境日益恶化，以色列军队逐渐逼近两家大型医院。

居民称，在以色列要求他们撤离后，又有数千名巴勒斯坦人沿着危险的前线道路从陷入困境的北部逃往南部。

但许多人仍留在北部，挤进希法医院和圣城医院，地面战斗在他们周围激烈进行，更多的以色列空袭从上空倾泻而下。

以色列称其哈马斯敌人在医院内设有指挥中心。

在巴黎，来自约 80 个国家和组织的官员举行会议，协调对加沙的人道主义援助，并寻找帮助受伤平民逃离目前已进入第二个月的围困的方法。

援助机构呼吁立即停火。

挪威难民理事会秘书长扬·埃格兰表示：“我们不能再等了。”他称以色列的行为是“集体惩罚”。

“如果不停火、解除围困、不分青红皂白的轰炸和战争，人类生命的流血事件将会继续。”

尽管以色列及其主要支持者美国拒绝全面停火，但他的呼吁得到了联合国和国际红十字会的响应。

10 月 7 日，哈马斯对以色列南部发动跨境袭击，以色列对加沙发动袭击，据以色列统计，枪手在袭击中杀害了 1,400 人，其中大部分是平民，并劫持了约 240 名人质。

这是以色列75年历史上最严重的流血事件，引起了国际社会对哈马斯的谴责以及对以色列的同情和支持。

但随着一场人道主义灾难的展开，以色列在哈马斯统治飞地的报复行动引起了人们的高度关注。

巴勒斯坦官员表示，截至周三，已有 10,569 名加沙居民在空袭和炮击中丧生，其中约 40% 是儿童，而基本物资已经耗尽，以色列无情的轰炸使一些地区成为废墟。

哈马斯据点加沙城的居民表示，以色列坦克驻扎在该地区周围。据报道，双方在激烈的巷战中互相造成重大伤亡。

誓言要消灭哈马斯的以色列表示，在向加沙市中心推进的地面行动中，有 33 名士兵丧生。

以色列军方周三表示，在与哈马斯和伊斯兰圣战武装分子进行了10个小时的地面和地下战斗后，以色列军队已经占领了加沙北部贾巴利亚的一个名为“17号院落”的哈马斯军事据点。

以色列军事镜头显示，士兵们穿过废墟进入一栋建筑，其中一堵墙被炸毁，找到了武器制造设备、指导手册和一个隧道竖井。

附近是一间女孩的卧室，有粉红色的墙壁、粉红色的衣柜和三张小床。

哈马斯武装派别表示，他们杀死的以色列士兵数量比军方公布的还要多，并摧毁了数十辆坦克、推土机和其他车辆。它发布了战斗机发射反坦克火箭并直接击中车辆的镜头。

无处可逃

尽管以色列下令撤离其包围的地区，但仍有数千名巴勒斯坦人前往加沙城内的希法医院寻求庇护。他们躲在医院场地的帐篷里，并表示他们无处可去。

联合国人道主义办公室人道协调厅表示，以色列再次要求北部居民向南迁移，连续第五天开放了一条长达四小时的走廊。据称，周三约有 5 万人离开该地区。

人道协调厅表示，主要道路周围的冲突和炮击仍在继续，危及撤离人员。报告称，尸体躺在路边，而大多数撤离者正在步行，因为以色列军方要求他们留下车辆。

一位不愿透露姓名的居民表示，他最初从靠近以色列边境的拜特哈农的家中避难到加沙城，随后与妻子和六个孩子（其中包括两个成年女儿）一起过境。

“没有出租车，你只能随身携带少量物品。你必须手里拿着身份证，在经过以色列坦克时举起它，然后再步行几公里寻找搭便车，”他说。

加沙 230 万人口中的大量流离失所者已经挤进了南部的学校、医院和其他场所。

以色列辛贝特安全部门前高级官员沙洛姆·本·哈南表示，靠近希法的战斗将对以色列军队构成挑战，因为部队可能需要疏散无视撤离警告的平民。

“他们（哈马斯）会向我们开枪，并会在医院里与我们作战，”他在耶路撒冷告诉路透社。 “我们将为此付出高昂的代价。”

尽管战斗集中在北部，但南部地区也经常受到攻击。

目击者称，周四上午，在加沙南部主要城市汗尤尼斯，居民们在以色列空袭摧毁的一座建筑的瓦砾和扭曲残骸中搜寻，希望找到幸存者。

停火呼吁

总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙在会议开幕时呼吁暂停人道主义援助。

巴勒斯坦权力机构表示，加沙地带是其未来巴勒斯坦国设想的一个组成部分。以色列官员表示，他们不打算在战后占领加沙，但尚未阐明如何确保安全。以色列于2005年从加沙撤军。

西班牙代理总理佩德罗·桑切斯在西班牙社会党（PSOE）周四获得加泰罗尼亚分离主义者朱特斯的支持组建政府后，看起来将再次连任。

根据路透社看到的西班牙工人社会党和联合工会联合声明，该协议中包括一项对因加泰罗尼亚试图脱离西班牙而被起诉的人给予特赦的法律。

领导谈判的社会党高级官员桑托斯·塞尔丹在布鲁塞尔举行的新闻发布会上表示，虽然社会党与联合党仍存在“深刻分歧”，但为了组建“稳定政府”，他们已将这些分歧搁置一旁。协议包括支持四年任期。

大赦的受益者之一是联合特派领导人卡尔斯·普伊格德蒙特 (Carles Puigdemont)，他目前流亡在比利时滑铁卢，因为他本人作为加泰罗尼亚领导人在分裂主义运动中面临不服从和贪污指控，该运动在投票和单方面声明中达到了顶峰。 2017年独立。

如果特赦获得国会批准，普伊格德蒙特将能够返回西班牙并有可能竞选公职。

在七月的选举没有产生彻底的胜利者后，桑切斯正试图组建政府。

他上个月与极左翼苏马尔纲领达成了联合执政协议，但还需要其他几个过去支持过他的小党派在最快下周举行的授职投票中支持他。

目前，即使有联合党的支持，社会党仍无法获得176个席位的绝对多数，无法在350个席位的国会中赢得第一轮投票，或者在第二轮投票中获得简单多数。

他们仍然需要巴斯克民族主义党（PNV）五名议员的支持，该党提供了早期支持，但表示将等待看到社会党与联合军协议的细节后再确认。

投票必须在 11 月 27 日之前结束，否则将自动触发新的选举。

大赦

如果实施特赦，多达1,400 名参与试图将加泰罗尼亚从西班牙分离的活动人士和政客将获得无罪。

谈判期间的关键症结在于特赦将涵盖哪些罪行，以及分裂分子是否准备明确放弃进一步的单方面行动。

西班牙研究委员会CSIC称，此次特赦将是西班牙自1977年对弗朗西斯科·佛朗哥独裁期间所犯罪行的全面宽恕以来最大规模的特赦，也是自1991年以来欧盟批准的首部特赦法。

可能的特赦遭到了桑切斯保守派对手的强烈谴责，他们组织了大规模抗议活动，并指责桑切斯为了自己的政治利益而将西班牙的法治置于危险之中。

针对周四达成协议的消息，主要反对党中右翼人民党发言人库卡·加马拉表示，西班牙正在考虑“一项可耻且令人羞辱的协议”。

周三，欧盟委员会司法专员迪迪埃·雷德尔斯致信西班牙政府，要求提供有关可能的特赦的更多细节。

他在给西班牙总统大臣费利佩·博拉诺斯的一封信中写道：“这已成为公众辩论中相当重要的问题，包括大量公民在内，已就此事与委员会联系。”

博拉诺斯周三回应称：“如果[在议会]登记特赦法案，请放心，我们将向您解释该法律的所有细节以及我国政府的立场。”

Nearly 70% of Portuguese voters want an early election following the abrupt resignation of the Socialist prime minister, a survey showed on Thursday, as President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa was due to announce his decision on the matter later in the day.

Antonio Costa stepped down on Tuesday after prosecutors detained his chief of staff in an investigation into alleged illegalities in his government's handling of lucrative lithium and hydrogen projects .

Prosecutors said Costa was also the target of a related probe. He has denied wrongdoing.

It is up to the conservative president to decide whether to allow the Socialist Party (PS), which has a parliamentary majority, to form a new or interim government, or to dissolve parliament and call an election.

His office said he would address the nation after meeting his consultative body, the Council of State. The meeting starts at 3 pm (1500 GMT).

A survey by Intercampus for newspapers Jornal de Negocios and Correio da Manha showed 67.8% of voters would prefer an early election, while 25.7% would rather see PS pick a new premier and form a government.

Analysts also see an election as the most likely option , although Rebelo de Sousa could choose to give more time to the PS to get next year's budget, already approved by parliament on first reading, over the line in parliament.

Joao Duque, dean of the Lisbon School of Economics and Management, said the president was likely to take into consideration Europe's volatile economic situation and allow lawmakers to vote on the budget bill, scheduled for Nov. 29.

PS President Carlos Cesar said on Wednesday that if the president decided to call an election, March would be the best timing. Other parties pointed to January or February.

The budget includes lower income tax rates for the middle class, higher wages and social benefits.

Separately, those detained in the investigation, including Costa's close friend and consultant Diogo Lacerda Machado, were due to appear before a Lisbon court on Thursday. They were suspected of crimes of corruption and influence-peddling, prosecutors said.

Reporting by Catarina Demony, Patricia Rua, Sergio Goncalves, editing by Andrei Khalip and Alex Richardson ; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 11:54:13 GMT IBFHMKZ455ISZDZOT7KUPMXBOE https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/poll-shows-most-portuguese-want-snap-election-president-readies-decision-2023-11-09/Reuters PORTUGAL POLITICS/ (PIX) With elections coming and relaxed sanctions, Venezuela is set to raise social spending

The Venezuelan government will be in a strong position to increase social spending to woo voters in 2024 as relief from some US sanctions allows more oil income to flow into government coffers, analysts say.

The United States in October temporarily rolled back some oil industry sanctions and lifted a ban on bond trading sanctions in exchange for an electoral deal between the government of President Nicolas Maduro and Venezuela's opposition.

Washington has conditioned an extension of the relief on the release of political prisoners and what it says are "wrongfully detained" Americans, as well as the lifting of public office bans on people including the winner of the opposition's primary nominating contest.

The relaxed sanctions could lead to $1.4 billion in additional income for Venezuela over the next six months, analyst firm Sintesis Financiera said in a report.

The additional oil income is expected to arrive gradually , partly though the redirection of exports. One oil industry source told Reuters they expect export income to grow by 40% per month.

Under the previous sanctions, state-run oil company PDVSA had to sell to Asian markets via intermediaries, a strategy that cut into government profits.

"The increase in income will be gradual," said Jose Vielma, a ruling party lawmaker and member of the finance committee for the government-allied national assembly. "The contribution will go to social spending and services."

The communications ministry and ruling party PSUV did not respond to requests for further comment on spending plans.

The increased income will almost certainly lead to greater financial laxity "given the need to improve popular support for the government ahead of elections in the second half of 2024," said Sintesis Financiera.

The government has traditionally increased social spending, public sector salaries, food distribution and housing construction projects ahead of elections, though national income has been limited over the last five years because of the sanctions and problems at PDVSA.

SALARY INCREASES?

If the sanctions relaxations continue next year and oil production goes up, the additional income could reach $7 billion in 2024, consulting firm Ecoanalitica said.

"In electoral periods clientelist spending increases, and it's possible we'll see workers getting bonuses or improvements in the distribution of food," said Venezuelan political consultant and analyst Oswaldo Ramirez.

"The challenge for the government is to convert that into votes... The ruling party has lost votes in part because of delays in salary increases and pensions," he said.

The government has already this year launched new social programs - which it calls "missions" - for young people and women, the first since 2017.

Such social programs distribute food, houses and even goods like motorcycle parts, cellphones and computer tablets.

Opposition figures have criticized the missions for more than a decade, saying they are a poor response to the destruction of Venezuela's economy by the ruling party, amount to "extortion by hunger," and that public funds could be better employed raising public sector salaries and pensions.

Economist Jose Guerra, a former opposition lawmaker and head of the non-governmental Venezuelan Finance Observatory, said public sector raises may still be too costly a prospect.

"The government will spend but not at the levels it did before," he said.

More income may also allow Maduro to revisit orthodox but insufficient inflation-fighting policies that have led to lower spending and less availability of credit , even as annual inflation reaches more than 300%.

Public spending has fallen to 15% of gross domestic product from 40% a decade ago, according to economic analysts. That has led teachers, nurses and other public workers to march for higher salaries as their wages shrink .

Some 2 million public workers earn between $45 and $60 per month, while private sector salaries are often more than $200, according to the Venezuelan Finance Observatory.

The central bank should mint fewer bolivares if there is higher oil income, several analysts said, estimating prices could fall in what remains of the year and take inflation down to 250% year-on-year.

Reporting by Mayela Armas and Deisy Buitrago Writing by Julia Symmes Cobb Editing by Rosalba O'Brien ; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 11:12:52 GMT HTQ6JIR5YJOTVLQJC2YXD27IXM https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/with-elections-coming-relaxed-sanctions-venezuela-is-set-raise-social-spending-2023-11-09/Mayela Armas, Deisy Buitrago VENEZUELA ECONOMY/SANCTIONS (PIX) As crisis deepens, Cubans scramble to migrate by any means

Cuban Idalberto Echavarria maneuvered his wife Olga in a wheelchair to the front of the line at Terminal 2 of Havana's airport, dodging luggage and a sea of people bidding farewell to friends and family.

The crowded terminal, a launch point for Cubans making their way by air to Nicaragua then overland to the United States, is one barometer of the frenzy to migrate from the communist-run island nation.

For many, like Echavarria and his wife, it has also become a last resort as Cuba's economic crisis deepens with no end in sight .

"There are other ways, but you need money or a family member outside the country," Echavarria told Reuters in an interview at the airport, referring to a refugee program introduced by the administration of US President Joe Biden in January that requires a US-based sponsor.

He and his wife, who is unable to walk due to a leg infection, have no retirement funds, no well-placed relatives in foreign countries and little access to legal entry programs, he said.

"For us, this was the only option, and the most difficult," said Echavarria. The couple plan to make the approximate 1,500-mile (2,400-km) trek through Central America by car.

The United States - the top destination for Cuban migrants -has since 2022 increased legal pathways to migration for Cubans, including visa access in Havana, in an effort to reduce illegal migration.

But more than a dozen interviews with would-be migrants this week at Havana embassies, municipal notaries and the airport suggest many, like Echavarria, either lack the means to apply for visa programs available on-island to Cubans or have lost patience waiting for their turn.

Despite the long onward journey, Nicaragua since 2021 has required no visa of Cuban migrants, and thus remains the easiest route to get to the US, several of those interviewed told Reuters.

While Key West in Florida lies little more than 90 miles from Cuba by water, the route is seen as risky and, unlike travel via Mexico, does not offer legal pathways for entry.

Echavarria said he did not want to cross the border illegally and would make an appointment for an asylum application via a US government app, CBP One , which migrants can access from Mexico.

Others told Reuters desperation was such that any route would do, even if it meant attempting to cross the US border illegally.

Just a few minutes from the airport, self-employed taxi driver Alain Ferguson, 27, said he had been left without friends by this most recent exodus.

"Go to the airport... almost everyone is leaving through Nicaragua," Ferguson said. "They don't care how they go, they just want to get out."

Nicaraguan officials did not immediately respond to a request for statistics on the number of Cubans entering the country by air.

But last month, Cuba's foreign ministry said it had detected "noticeable growth" in the movement of its migrants across irregular routes north through Central America in past months, though it did not release statistics.

About 10,700 Cubans were encountered at the US-Mexico border in September, up from around 6,200 a month earlier, according to US government statistics. Levels of border arrivals, however, are still lower than a year ago, when fewer legal avenues existed to apply from abroad.

'I GOT LUCKY'

Artist Ernesto Perez, 51, told Reuters he had waited since 2015 for his turn to enter the United states legally under a family reunification program. When that didn't work, he applied for the sponsorship program.

"Not having a response since 2015, one gets desperate," Perez said outside the US embassy in Havana as he stood in line for his long-awaited interview. "It crossed my mind to go through Nicaragua ... but I decided to wait a little more and I got lucky."

Cuba blames the long-running US trade embargo and Trump-era sanctions for fueling the economic crisis and the exodus of more than 400,000 Cubans leaving for the United States in the last two years.

The US says the sanctions are necessary to promote human rights and fundamental liberties in Cuba and that it makes exceptions for humanitarian purposes.

Senior US Department of State official Brian Nichols said on social media this week he was "concerned by reports of a dramatic increase in Nicaragua-bound charter flights that facilitate irregular migration from Cuba and elsewhere to the United States."

A defective drone in Iraq may have helped keep America from being dragged deeper into a widening Middle East conflict.

The drone, which was launched at the Erbil air base by an Iranian-backed militia before sunrise on Oct. 26, penetrated US air defenses and crashed into the second floor of the barracks housing American troops at about 5 am, according to two US officials familiar with the matter.

But the device laden with explosives failed to detonate and in the end only one service member suffered a concussion from the impact, said the officials, who asked to remain anonymous to speak freely about the attack. The US had got lucky, they added, as the drone could have caused carnage had it exploded.

The incident was among at least 40 separate drone and rocket attacks that have been launched at US forces by Iranian-backed militias in Iraq and Syria over the past three weeks in response to American support for Israel in the Gaza war, according to Pentagon data and the two US officials.

The bombardment has only caused a few dozen minor injuries so far, with many of the rockets and one-way attack drones intercepted by US air defenses in Iraq and Syria, where a total of 3,400 American troops are based.

David Schenker, a former US assistant secretary of state at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy think-tank, cautioned that while neither Iran and its allied groups nor the US appeared to want a direct confrontation, the risks were growing. The possibility of a major strike that draws America into a conflict is "a very realistic concern," he said.

"I think they are calibrating the attacks to harass rather than kill en masse US troops," he said of Iraqi and Syrian militias. "But there's a lot more they can do."

It's unclear how President Joe Biden would respond to a major attack that kills a large number of Americans. Struggling in opinion polls ahead of next year's presidential election, Biden has so far sought to limit the US role in the conflict mostly to ensuring military aid to Israel.

The war broke out when gunmen from Hamas - the Iranian-funded militant group that rules the Palestinian enclave of Gaza - burst into southern Israel on Oct. 7, killing 1,400 people, mostly civilians, and taking more than 240 hostages. Since then, Israel has bombarded the coastal territory relentlessly, killing more than 10,000 people, many of them children.

Iran says it had no role in Hamas' Oct. 7 raid on Israel, though it has welcomed the attack.

On Sunday, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken flew to Iraq - where most of the attacks on US forces have taken place - to push Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia Al-Sudani to crack down on the militias operating there and avert any escalation.

Yet Sudani has had little luck in persuading the militia groups from letting up their assault, or convincing their bankrollers in Iran to rein them in, according to five senior lawmakers in Sudani's governing coalition, a security adviser to the premier and a militia commander.

The prime minister and around 10 senior members of his government met with the commanders of about a dozen militia groups in Baghdad on Oct. 23 to press the groups to halt their attacks on US forces, said the seven people, who were either present or were briefed on the meeting.

The plea largely fell on deaf ears, though, with most of the commanders vowing to keep up their assault until Israeli forces ended their siege and bombardment of the Gaza Strip, they added.

"No one - not the prime minister or anyone else - can stand against our religious duty," said Ali Turki, a Shi'ite lawmaker in the governing coalition as well as a commander with the powerful Iranian-backed Asaib Ahl al-Haq militia.

Arif al-Hamami, another Shi'ite lawmaker, said the prospects for diplomacy looked bleak: "I don't think that the prime minister has the power to stop the attacks as long as Israel is committing atrocities in Gaza with American help."

The Iraqi and Iranian governments didn't immediately respond to requests for comment on the militia attacks and the risk of escalation.

IRAQ LEADER'S APPEAL TO IRAN

Iraq's prime minister has limited control over the militias, whose support he needed to win power a year ago and now form a powerful bloc in his governing coalition. The militant groups, which proliferated in Iraq in the wake of the US-led invasion in 2003 that toppled Saddam Hussein and his Sunni government, are trained and funded by Shi'ite power Iran.

For Sudani, it's been a case of shuttle-diplomacy.

Hours after meeting Blinken on Sunday, the premier flew to Tehran to directly appeal to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and other Iranian officials for help, according to a senior Iraqi politician close to the prime minister who was briefed on the visit.

Sudani asked the Iranian officials to pressure the militias into halting their attacks on US forces in Iraq, fearing his politically and economically unstable country could ill afford an escalation that would see the Americans strike back against the militants, the politician said.

The officials told him that the militias in Iraq made their own decisions and Tehran wouldn't interfere in the situation there, the politician added.

Iran has decried the retaliatory Israeli assault on Gaza as a genocide and warned that if it isn't halted, the US will not be "spared from this fire." Meanwhile, the Hezbollah movement backed by Tehran in Lebanon - a group that sources say have acquired powerful Russian anti-ship missiles - has warned Washington that it would pay a heavy price in a regional war.

'LAUGHING AT US IN TEHRAN'

Biden faces his own dilemmas as he receives a steady stream of reports about hostilities in the region. Among attacks outside Iraq and Syria in recent weeks, Iranian-aligned Houthi fighters unleashed 15 drones and four cruise missiles off the coast of Yemen that were shot down by US Navy destroyer with a crew of hundreds of sailors, US military officials say.

The present crisis has erupted following years of steady US withdrawal of military assets from the Middle East, including air defenses, as Washington seeks to focus on Russia's invasion in Ukraine and mounting tensions with China. That refocus accelerated after Biden's complete pullout from Afghanistan and the Taliban's takeover there two years ago.

The response by Biden has been cautious so far;上个月，他下令对叙利亚境内两个与伊朗有关的武器储存设施进行连夜袭击，当时这些设施尚未被占领，但他没有下令对伊拉克进行任何袭击。 On Wednesday, Biden followed up with a similar strike in Syria and US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin cautioned: "We urge against any escalation."

Biden has warned Iranian-backed groups across the region, including the large Hezbollah movement in Lebanon, against expanding the conflict but he and other officials have declined to be explicit about what they would do in response.

The US hopes a military show of force will dissuade any serious attack and has deployed two aircraft carrier strike groups and even taken the rare step over the weekend of announcing that an Ohio-class submarine had moved to the region.

Beyond sending air defenses like the Patriot system and a high-altitude system, the US military is also taking additional steps to protect its tens of thousands of troops in the region, according to officials.

The measures include beefing up security at US military bases in the region by increasing patrols, restricting access and boosting intelligence gathering, they said.

The response to the crisis from Biden, a Democrat, hasn't been strong enough for many of his critics, including Republicans in Congress.

"They are laughing at us in Tehran," said Republican Senator Tom Cotton, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. "Iran will continue to target Americans until President Biden gets serious about imposing severe costs on Iran."

At a hearing with Austin on Oct. 31, Republican Senator Lindsey Graham repeatedly asked if the deaths of US service members would trigger a direct response against Iran. Austin demurred, only saying that Iran should be held "accountable."

"I wish you would be more clear, because if one of these soldiers is killed..." Graham said, pausing for effect.

For some, the recent attacks on US troops stir painful memories of the massive truck bomb in Beirut that shredded a Marine barracks, killing 241 US service members, 40 years ago last month. The United States holds Hezbollah responsible for the suicide bombing though the group has denied involvement.

David Madaras was a 22-year-old Marine when the concussive wave hit him from the explosion in 1983. As he recalls digging through the rubble where some of his friends were buried, he sees modern-day parallels that make him uneasy.

"We had rocket attacks, mortar attacks, before we got hit with the big bomb," he said. "Does history repeat itself?"

“我在村子里为朋友和亲戚唱歌，我们举办了很多聚会，唱歌聚会，”萨利赫·扎达在他亲戚的一套拥挤的低收入社区公寓里说道。他向路透社展示了他演奏风琴和鲁巴布（一种弦乐器）的视频片段，其中一些视频出现在社交媒体上。

“我的家人建议我离开阿富汗，我害怕塔利班，”他说，并补充说，由于他没有有效签证，担心被巴基斯坦警察逮捕，这让他连续几天呆在家里。

“这里（巴基斯坦）的生活很困难，但我必须保住自己的生命。”

纪伯伦·佩希曼 (Gibran Peshimam) 撰写；编辑：Raju Gopalakrishnan ; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 08:01:53 GMT D6VCS67VJJIC5O3IWRCU3GOX4U https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/keeping-lights-off-undocumented-afghans-go-underground-pakistan-2023-11-09/Ariba Shahid, Mohammad Yunus Yawar移民巴基斯坦/阿富汗地下（PIX、电视） Private jets of Russian oligarchs keep flying but not to EuropeSummary:
  • 白俄罗斯取代法国里维埃拉，与寡头有联系
  • 自乌克兰战争以来，约50架私人飞机在俄罗斯重新注册
  • 制裁限制了目的地，更难获得备件
  • 现在飞往土耳其、迪拜、中国、前苏联国家

乌克兰战争前两年，一架与俄罗斯寡头弗拉基米尔·叶夫图申科夫有联系的私人波音 737 飞机纵横全球，飞抵法国里维埃拉、马尔代夫、塞舌尔以及世界各国首都和金融中心。

Flightradar24 的航班跟踪数据显示，今年，这架飞机不再是传统的富人游乐场，而是多次访问了前苏联国家吉尔吉斯斯坦、哈萨克斯坦和白俄罗斯，以及中国。

路透社报道称，俄罗斯一些富人和权贵正在想方设法让私人飞机保持空中飞行，这表明自莫斯科入侵乌克兰以来西方制裁的局限性和影响范围，但这些限制大大限制了飞机的飞行范围。

路透社查阅的截至 8 月初的国家飞机登记数据显示，自 2022 年 2 月入侵以来，至少有 50 架私人飞机重新登记在俄罗斯国旗下，这架与叶夫图申科夫有关的波音飞机是其中之一。

据俄罗斯航空业两位资深消息人士透露，几架被遣返的私人飞机与知名政界人士和商界人士有联系，他们没有被授权接受媒体采访，因此不愿透露姓名。

Jetphotos 网站上的图片显示，两位消息人士称，叶夫图申科夫亲自使用过波音 737，直到去年，这架飞机还带有他创立的电信木材集团 AFK Sistema (AFKS.MM)的标志。

叶夫图申科夫表示，他不会回答有关这架飞机的问题，包括他是否使用这架飞机。去年英国对叶夫图申科夫实施制裁后，他正式放弃了对 Sistema 的控制权。他仍然是该集团的主要股东。

俄罗斯航空管理局和交通运输部没有回应置评请求。没有迹象表明与这些飞机有关的公司在遣返或正在进行的航班方面违反了任何制裁措施。

一些飞机滞留

包括阿鲁巴岛和马恩岛在内的司法管辖区（部分飞机此前已在这些地区注册）遵守西方的制裁措施。其中一位消息人士称，这使得悬挂其国旗飞行的俄罗斯飞机很难获得保险、燃油和许可证。

将飞机挂上俄罗斯国旗后，它们可以往返于未实施飞行禁令或个人旅客不受制裁的国家，包括土耳其和迪拜。

该消息人士根据对该行业的广泛了解估计，尽管采取了这些举措，但俄罗斯约 400 架私人和企业喷气机机队中，有一半以上仍然滞留在国外或已被出售。

清单显示，俄罗斯旗下的公务机总数目前为 145 架，而截至 2022 年 3 月上旬，共有 97 架。

尾数显示，由于制裁，俄罗斯飞机被禁止进入欧盟 27 个国家，俄罗斯寡头此前经常飞往欧盟进行商务和休闲活动，许多与他们相关的私人飞机在战前就已在欧盟注册。

两位组织和管理公务机的航空消息人士表示，一些飞机所有者从俄罗斯飞往土耳其或前苏联国家，然后包租不同的飞机飞往欧盟机场，前提是这些人没有受到个人制裁。

一位消息人士补充说，这种做法的例子至少每周发生一次，但没有给出具体例子。

根据海关数据，部分被遣返的飞机与在乌克兰战争中支持普京总统或与普京有联系的国有企业和商界领袖有联系。

其中包括一架庞巴迪挑战者 650，数据显示该飞机是由乌拉卡利公司进口的，该公司是一家大型化肥生产商，前德米特里·马泽平 (Dmitry Mazepin) 领导，今年早些时候参加了普京领导的企业家聚会的大亨之一。

VEB.RF 是前第一副总理伊戈尔·舒瓦洛夫 (Igor Shuvalov) 领导的国有开发银行，进口了一架庞巴迪 Global 6000。

VEB、乌拉尔卡利和马泽平没有回应就这些飞机在俄罗斯注册的置评请求。

海关数据显示，战争爆发后遣返的大部分私人飞机都是从前苏联国家以及阿联酋和土耳其返回俄罗斯的。

Flightradar24 的数据显示，与与叶夫图申科夫有关的波音飞机的情况一样，其他重新注册的飞机也避免进入欧盟领空，并一直飞往被认为对俄罗斯友好的国家。

被剪掉的翅膀

Jetphotos 网站上的一张图片显示，2021 年 12 月，这架波音飞机在布拉格停机坪上被拍到，上面挂有阿鲁巴国旗，注册号为 P4-AFK。这架飞机有灰色条纹，尾部有 Sistema 标志。

根据 Jetphotos 上的一张照片，仅仅一年多后，战争开始后，这架飞机就出现在吉尔吉斯斯坦的比什凯克。尾号已更改为俄罗斯注册 RA-73890，并且 Sistema 徽标已被删除。

但发动机盖上仍然带有 P4-AFK 标识，并且灰色条纹仍然存在。

Sistema 拒绝就这架飞机或其所有权发表评论。美国于 11 月 2 日将 Sistema 列入制裁名单。

从 2020 年初到入侵乌克兰（俄罗斯官员称之为“特别军事行动”）期间，P4-AFK 多次前往德国、卢森堡、瑞士和马尔代夫，并分别前往克罗地亚、捷克共和国和塞舌尔群岛，Flightradar24数据显示。

它还在俄罗斯进行了105次，在法国进行了17次，在意大利、阿拉伯联合酋长国和拉脱维亚进行了8次，在英国进行了5次，在土耳其进行了4次。

入侵开始后，这架飞机在 2022 年剩余时间内在土耳其、阿联酋、阿曼和哈萨克斯坦的机场之间飞行，从未进入欧盟领土。在此期间，该公司仅进行了 14 趟航班。

根据 Rosaviatiya 网站 8 月份发布的俄罗斯飞机登记信息，这架飞机于 12 月底在俄罗斯国旗下注册。

海关数据显示，该机于12月30日从前苏联成员国吉尔吉斯斯坦首都比什凯克正式进口至俄罗斯，此后其航班基本上仅限于俄罗斯。

2023年迄今为止，该航班已在俄罗斯境内执飞47次，飞往哈萨克斯坦、吉尔吉斯斯坦、白俄罗斯和中国的航班总计9次。
